posts.title: L’Enclos
posts.excerpt: This prison camp drama by director and co-scripter Armand Gatti, his first film, reflects the early ’60s resurgence of interest in the crimes against humanity committed by the Nazis in World War II. (In another year, the Adolph Eichmann trial would be the first ever seen live on American television.) Gatti focuses on two men …

posts._title: Ki-duk Kim – Suchwiin bulmyeong AKA Address Unknown (2001)
posts.title: Suchwiin bulmyeong
posts.excerpt: Romances end in blood and the frail hopes of individuals are torn apart in a vile karmic continuity of colonialism…Address Unknown (2001) is Kim Ki-Duk’s most political film so far which traces the scars left by the Korean war of the 1950s and its contemporary reverberations on a US Army base.

posts.title: Separate Tables
posts.excerpt: Description: It’s the off-season at the lonely Beauregard Hotel in Bournemoth, and only the long-term tenants are still in residence. Life at the Beauregard is stirred up, however, when the beautiful Ann Shankland arrives to see her alcoholic ex-husband, John Malcolm, who is secretly engaged to Pat Cooper, the woman who runs the hotel. posts.title: Regeneration
posts.excerpt: Raoul Walsh had just come off The Birth of a Nation both as one of Griffith’s assistant directors and as an actor (most prominently as John Wilkes Booth), when he made this film.
